subNodes.conversationText:
As was walking through the forest, came upon a boy walking the other direction. He was not older than thirteen or so. He carried a small hatchet in one hand and a split log in the other. On his back was strapped a bundle of sticks.

Pharaoh, sometimes shy around strangers, flew into a nearby tree to observe the meeting.
When the boy saw <FirstName>, he stopped dead in his tracks and eyed <him/her> warily.
"Hello," said <FirstName>. "I didn't mean to startle you."

He only looked up and down in response. Finally, he spoke.

"Who are you?"

He only looked up and down in response. Finally, he spoke.

"Who are you?"

He only looked up and down in response. Finally, he spoke.

"Who are you?"

"Oh." 

<FirstName> was taken aback. As a rule, children are less nonchalant about witches.

"What's that?" the boy asked, pointing to something on the ground.

There lay a perfectly normal gourd. "Aha," thought to self. "Eldest Lady took care to keep Knott secret from ordinary folk."

"It's rotten," he said. It didn't seem that way to <FirstName>. If anything, it looked healthier and more vibrant than other gourds <he/she> remembered. Perhaps the child had never seen a gourd before.
"I should go," the boy said abruptly, studying the sun through the trees. "Dad'll be angry that I'm taking so long."
He hoisted his hatchet onto his shoulder and adjusted his satchel.
"Then you take after him," said <FirstName>, pointing at the hatchet.
"Doesn't he worry about you being out here by yourself?"
"Doesn't he worry about you being out here by yourself?"
The boy went off into the forest. The moment he was gone, Knott rematerialized beside <FirstName>. It took the promise of kernels, however, to coax Pharaoh from his perch.
"Isn't it dangerous for you to be out here by yourself?"
"Fairies? Oh -- them. They don't bother me."
"Who is your father, by the way?"
The boy went off into the forest. The moment he was gone, Knott rematerialized beside <FirstName>. It took the promise of kernels, however, to coax Pharaoh from his perch.
The boy went off into the forest. The moment he was gone, Knott rematerialized beside <FirstName>. It took the promise of kernels, however, to coax Pharaoh from his perch.
"I should go," he said, studying the moon through the trees. "Dad'll be angry that I'm taking so long."
The boy accepted this with no change of expression. His eyes were still fixed on the gourd.

"It's rotten," he said. It didn't seem that way to <FirstName>. If anything, it looked healthier and more vibrant than other gourds <he/she> remembered. Perhaps the child had never seen a gourd before.

"Oh. You tell riddles."

hadn't meant to tell a riddle. wondered what the boy meant.

He bent down a little, getting a better look at the gourd.

"It's rotten," he said. It didn't seem that way to <FirstName>. If anything, it looked healthier and more vibrant than other gourds <he/she> remembered. Perhaps the child had never seen a gourd before.

"It's rotten," he said. It didn't seem that way to <FirstName>. If anything, it looked healthier and more vibrant than other gourds <he/she> remembered. Perhaps the child had never seen a gourd before.
"I'm investigating something bad that happened in these woods."
"Oh." The boy glanced at his hatchet.
"Yes. Perhaps you know something that can help me."
"No. Not my business." He spoke very firmly for someone so young.

"What's that?" the boy asked, pointing to something on the ground.

There lay a perfectly normal gourd. "Aha," thought to self. "Eldest Lady took care to keep Knott secret from ordinary folk."
"Gathering firewood?" said <FirstName> in a friendly tone.

He only looked up and down in response. Finally, he spoke.

"Who are you?"
